content: I see in the Dandelion++ paper they are speaking of dandalion epochs "in the order of 10 minutes". That clearly does not fit all of our use cases, and goes against our efforts to reduce inclusion times and finality.

author: cskiraly
content:
I admit I'm not too familiar with Dandelion++, but I see some signs that makes me suspicios.
- The paper I'm seeing cites only very few works, while the literature on PETs is wast and goes way back in time.
- It also admittedly changes many fundamental parts of Dandelion, because of "simplifying assumptions made in Dandelion ... can lead to serious deanonymization attacks". What makes then Dandelion a good basis at all?
- While the abstract appeared in Sigmetrics, which is a good sign, I don't see a full paper going through peer review, which is not a good sign in anonymity research.

And, then, there are papers like this: https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.11860
 I did not go through this second one, but it states "we model Dandelion, Dandelion++ and Lightning Network. We study different configurations and demonstrate that none of them offers acceptable anonymity to their users"

Before going down that rabbit hole, I would take a critical look at what's the right basis to use.

author: cskiraly
content: Correction, now I've found the full paper. It already seems much more serious üôÇ

author: cskiraly
content: As for combining with onion encryption: one problem I see is that onion encryption requires source routing on the overlay (source routing means the source decides the whole path, there are no routing decision along the path, as e.g. in Tor). I might be wrong, but I don't think that combines well with the forwarding policies in Dendalion++.
